title: Before 1 July 2020, will the Chilean government pass legislation that caps administrative fees and/or operating profits of the country's pension fund managers?
preds: 1st July seems a bit difficult at the moment.

Before 1 July 2020, will the Chilean government pass legislation that caps administrative fees and/or operating profits of the country's pension fund managers?
Reducing my forecast by 100%.

Before 1 July 2020, will the Chilean government pass legislation that caps administrative fees and/or operating profits of the country's pension fund managers?
Hattip for a great analysis to @dlaiocean, who brought me back to reality.

Read  Ministra Schmidt's statements in todays La Tercera, and draw your own conclusions.  https://www.latercera.com/pulso/noticia/no-podemos-descuidar-las-pensiones-del-futuro-ministra-zaldivar-reacciona-propuesta-mesa-tecnica-la-oposicion/972886/

Lets examine the facts before forecasting this question. In December 2017, the total assets managed by the Chilean private AFPs are US$ 211 billion (1).  The AFPs registered a earning of US$197 million for the first quarter in 2019 (2).  This extrapolates to about US$800 million per year.  This results in roughly 0.4% of the total assets (I know I am mixing the years but the general conclusion should not change much).  It does not appear to be excessive.  This percentage is also in line with what is reported in an OECD report (3) - the Chilean pension fund fee is 0.6% of the salary. In 2017, the fund with the highest risk profile, fund A, performed the best over the 12 months, generating returns of 15.44% (1).   The worst performing fund was the most conservative, fund E, which generated returns of 1.01%. Fund C, with an intermediate risk level, generated returns of 7.51%.  These are respectable performances. It appears that the low pension in Chile is not due to excessive fees or poor performance.  Low contributions are frequently cited as the cause of the low pension payouts.  Reducing fees (in fact, removal of all fees) will not make significant increases in pension payouts.  However, government policies are frequently based on politics and not rational assessment of facts.  There is a small chance that this is going to happen.    (1)  https://www.bnamericas.com/en/news/insurance/chile-afps-pass-us210bn-aum-milestone-in-2017
(2) https://www.bnamericas.com/en/news/chile-pension-debate-in-focus-again-as-afps-double-profits
(3) https://www.oecd-ilibrary.org/docserver/pension_glance-2017-38-en.pdf?expires=1578945702&id=id&accname=guest&checksum=E744CC107B4C729C8ABCE4EDE8B739B4

Before 1 July 2020, will the Chilean government pass legislation that caps administrative fees and/or operating profits of the country's pension fund managers?
On second thought, the only victims here are the financial funds and it's "doing something".

Before 1 July 2020, will the Chilean government pass legislation that caps administrative fees and/or operating profits of the country's pension fund managers?
This just doesn't appear to be feasible, regardless of how emotionially satisfying it may appear.
What if it only applies to FONASA?
I’ve explained my rationale in the companion question.
So many pissed off pensioners are not getting what was promised by govt 30 years ago. They blame fees and corruption state overlooked but promoted.
No real knowledge here - just assuming this is unlikely, but no so unlikely that the question wouldn't be asked.

While a full nationalization is unlikely prior to 1 July, this initiative could gain support as an additional stop-gap prior to negotiations for a new constitution.  Efforts to address the unrest thus far have been unsuccessful, but the President could push for such a measure to improve his approval ratings as the country moves toward reform.

The argument is that there is a problem with contributions. Fees and operating profits are not transparent, and it doesn't solve the problem of low pensions. I don't think they will move to do this, particularly in this time period.
